articles.title: The Web Just Gets Better with Interop 2024
articles.description: Jen runs through the focus areas for the collective Interop project for this year, which include accessibility improvements, custom properties, scrollbar styling, and ironing out differences with CSS Nesting. Here's Mozilla's post on the 2024 plans, and the same from Google and Microsoft. The Web's better when we all work together...
articles.author: Jen Simmons (WebKit)

articles.title: 'Interaction to Next Paint' Becomes a Core Web Vital on March 12
articles.description: INP, described as a "better way to measure interaction responsiveness", will replace First Input Delay (FID) next month. Here the Chrome team shares how to prepare for this metric change, and what to expect once the change takes effect.
articles.author: Wagner & Viscomi (Chrome)

articles.title: Getting Into Web Components: An Intro
articles.description: 2024 looks like it might be a big one for web components. So, if you want to gain a deeper understanding of things this is a good place to start, as Brecht outlines some of the basics and lingo you’ll need to know.
articles.author: Brecht De Ruyte

articles.title: 💰 What Happened with the Web Monetization API?
articles.description: This neat idea had a brief moment, but then seemed to wither away — though efforts to revive it could be on the way..
articles.author: Chris Coyier

articles.title: The Color Input and Color Picker
articles.description: HTML has a color input that is supported across the board, but browsers can and do have different approaches to what happens when the input is used. Chris takes a look at the differences.
articles.author: Chris Coyier

articles.title: Doing What’s Required: Indicating Mandatory Fields in An Accessible Way
articles.description: Curious as to the best and most accessible method to indicate required fields? This article explains what’s required in a compliant way.
articles.author: David Swallow

articles.title: 🧊 How to Embed 3D Models on the Web
articles.description: How do you embed 3D models on pages without things slowing down? Jason looks at the file formats, model viewers, UX, optimizations, and proposed standards in the space.
articles.author: Jason Grigsby

articles.title: The Psychology of Site Speed and Human Happiness
articles.description: If you don’t consider time a crucial usability factor, you’re missing a fundamental aspect of the user experience, says Tammy.
articles.author: Tammy Everts (Speedcurve)

articles.title: Big, Beautiful, Beefy Focus States with :focus-visible
articles.description: :focus-visible solves the “I want keyboard focus but not click focus” problem by treating keyboards and pointers separate.
articles.author: Dave Rupert

articles.title: Jakob Nielsen's 41 Years in UX: A Career Retrospective
articles.description: A detailed look back from usability guru Jakob Nielsen: “my mission has remained absolutely constant for all of my 41 years in UX: make computers suitable for normal humans instead of forcing users to adapt to the technology”.
articles.author: Jakob Nielsen

articles.title: 🅇 In Loving Memory of the Square Checkbox
articles.description: A brief history of checkboxes and radio buttons in user interfaces.
articles.author: Nikita Prokopov

articles.title: CSSformalize: A CSS Framework for Effortless Customization of Native HTML Forms
articles.description: Offers an interactive UI to allow you to set your CSS custom properties for just about every aspect of your form, with live preview of the form elements, and optional predesigned themes.
articles.author: Pelin Oleg

articles.title: 📅 Calendar.js: A Calendar Control with Drag and Drop
articles.description: A no-dependencies responsive calendar with full drag and drop support, plus lots of ways to manage events with recurring entries, exporting, holidays, and more.
articles.author: William Troup

articles.title: Baklava: A Component Design System Based on Native Web Components
articles.description: This is more of a front-end framework than a design system and all the components are using native web components, so they can easily be integrated with your existing framework.
articles.author: Trendyol

articles.title: Svelte Stepper: Build Animated Stepped Flows with Svelte
articles.description: You can add and customize props on the component to easily adjust the number of steps and transition duration, among other features. Simple demo here.
articles.author: Jason Efstathiou
